description: Join us for new & unique indoor fun every Sunday in February!   Schedule of events at each location for Sundays in February Carnival Games - Try your hand at Plinko, ring/frisbee toss or challenge others to a giant game of Connect 4!  Racket and Roll -  Badminton, Pickleball even Table Tennis - choose your racquet and serve!  Family Fitness/Art Frenzy -  Workout together in our family-friendly fitness circuit and cool down while creating a Family Tree art project.   Super Sports Fest - Visit each station to test your skills in basketball, soccer, gymnastics to name a few!    Other activities include a bouncy house, obstacle courses, tunnels, scooters and more!       No pre-registration required. Non-members welcome when paying a drop-in fee. Table tennis not available at West Portage. Bouncy house not available at South.
location: 3550 Portage Ave, Winnipeg, MB R3K 0Z8, Canada

description: Looking for a break at the end of a long week? Perhaps a little “me time”? Or just the opportunity to have an evening out? Register your kids in our Kid’s Night Out!   Children 5-12 years of age will have a fun-filled night of active games and creative play with our energetic Y staff and volunteers. Child-friendly supper and snacks included!
location: 5 Fermor Ave, Winnipeg, MB R2M 3N8, Canada

description: Our Spring session registration will open at noon on Monday, March 10 both in person and on-line.  Programs include swim lessons, gymnastics, karate, basketball as well as summer day camp!  Programs & lessons are available for Y members aged 3 to 12 years of age.   Note: Summer day camp registration is open to both members and non-members.
location: 3550 Portage Ave, Winnipeg, MB R3K 0Z8, Canada

description: Looking for a break at the end of a long week? Perhaps a little “me time”? Or just the opportunity to have an evening out? Register your kids in our Kid’s Night Out! event_name: Shoppers Drug Mart® Run for Women 2025
description: Your donations and participation support women's mental health programs at Women’s College Hospital. When you take part in the Run for Women, you are impacting the lives of thousands of women across Canada by creating access to life-changing mental healthcare where, when, and how they need it most.    When you walk or run, you support:  Women’s College Hospital’s Mental Health Programs – the largest clinical and research program of its kind in Canada.  Over 30,000 patient visits each year – a number that will grow exponentially as virtual care initiatives continue to grow in scope and impact.  Specialty areas of focus that include trauma and abuse, mental health during reproductive life stages, medical psychiatry and refugee mental health.  Virtual care initiatives pioneered at WCH that are breaking down barriers and improving access.   Innovative new programs and research that ensure women have the support they need when they need it most.
location: Women's College Hospital, 76 Grenville Street, Toronto, ON M5S 1B2, Canada

description: On March 21 – 22, basketball stars will converge on Toronto for the 6th annual West Park Foundation Tournament of Stars.  At this unique, two-day basketball event you’ll have the opportunity to team up with former Toronto Raptors and other NBA and WNBA alumni for a fun but competitive tournament in support of UHN-West Park Healthcare Centre.   Tournament of Stars kicks off with the Friday night Celebrity Draft Party, an exclusive cocktail reception during which qualifying teams draft their celebrity player and meet to plot their game day strategy. The team that raises the most money for West Park gets top pick in the draft!  On Saturday, the energy builds from the moment the teams hit the courts and the games begin. Teams will enjoy showcasing their skills on the court playing alongside NBA & WNBA alums as they compete for the tournament trophy, while family and friends cheer them on from the bleachers.  Join us for an action-packed, family-friendly day of basketball in support of West Park.
location: Goldring Centre 100 Devonshire Place, Toronto, ON  M5S 2C9

event_name: UHN’s West Park Healthcare Centre and Toronto Public Health Present the 2025 World TB Day Conference: TB Horizons: Advancing Diagnosis, Treatment, and Prevention
description: UHN’s West Park Healthcare Centre has a 120-year history of providing exemplary care to tuberculosis patients. Founded in 1904 as a TB sanitorium, today West Park is the province’s designated centre for treating resistant tuberculosis and mycobacterial infections, while leading national efforts in rehabilitation.  On World TB Day 2025, West Park and Toronto Public Health invite clinicians in the TB field and public health agencies to attend our conference: “TB Horizons: Advancing Diagnosis, Treatment, and Prevention.”
location: West Park Healthcare Centre – 170 Emmett Ave, Toronto M6M 2J5

description: Please join us at UHN’s West Park Healthcare Centre for a reception to celebrate the opening of the art installations enriching lives in our new hospital building.  Take a tour, hear a keynote presentation by Sara Angel, Founder and Executive Director of Art Canada Institute and meet the artists whose work enhances the patient experience including:  Dr. Chris Boulias, Mike Hammer, April Hickox, Lucie Johnson on behalf of Richard Johnson, Dennis Lin, Elizabeth McIntosh, Tom Miller, Bill Schwarz, and patient artists Funds raised will support the inspiring vision for West Park’s ongoing art strategy to advance the collection and fund an Artists in Residence Program.

event_name: How To Become A Volunteer: Newcomers
description: In collaboration with the Toronto Public Library, discover how to safely get involved as a volunteer. Learn where to search for opportunities and how to find the best match for your needs and goals - including volunteering virtually from home, or in person with a group or organization.    You’ll also discover thousands of free online resources through the Toronto Public Library to help you learn more about the city, make community connections, and access other helpful support services. This session is great for newcomers and anyone who wants to make a positive impact on our city, or improve or learn new skills.  This session is Free and No Registration is needed to attend. If you would like to receive a reminder email, then click Here to receive a reminder.     Please note:  You will not receive volunteer hours for attending this session.
location: Toronto Public Library - Agincourt Branch 155 Bonis Ave, Toronto Scarborough, Ontario  M1T 3W6 Canada

event_name: High School Volunteering: Ask Me Anything
description: Are you a high school student?  Looking to volunteer during March break?  Want to finish your school community hours?  Join us and learn how to get involved as a volunteer, where to search for opportunities and how to find the best match for your needs and goals. During the session you can ask us any questions about volunteering as a high school student. This session is intended for youth and anyone in high school.     Please note: You will Not receive volunteer hours for attending this session.

event_name: How To Become A  Leadership Volunteer
description: In collaboration with the Toronto Public Library, discover how to safely get involved as a leadership volunteer. Participants will   - Understand what leadership volunteering means. - Explore available leadership volunteer roles and how to determine the right role and organization.  - Learn about volunteering with a non-profit’s board of directors, and how to apply to become a board member.    Please note: You will not receive volunteer hours for attending this webinar.

description: Looking to volunteer during March break?  Want to finish your school community hours?  Join us at Toronto Public Library Bloor and Gladstone branch, on Tuesday February 25, 2025 at 6.30pm to learn more!  Understand the Library services and volunteer opportunities. Discover how to safely get involved as a volunteer.  Learn where to search for opportunities and how to find the best match for your needs and goals. Understand the application process and what to expect. This session is great for high school students, youth and anyone who wants to make a positive impact on our city, or improve or learn new skills.  This event is Free, no registration is needed to attend.  Please note: You will not receive volunteer hours for attending this webinar.
location: Toronto Public Library - Bloor and Gladstone Branch 1101 Bloor St W Toronto M6H 1M7 Canada

description: What makes a volunteer "difficult?" What are the rules and unspoken boundaries that impact volunteer engagement? Effectively dealing with difficult volunteers starts with setting clear expectations, understanding why volunteers break the rules and exploring consequences that make sense. This interactive, two-hour in-person workshop will address challenges you might encounter with both virtual and in-person volunteers, and will also discuss alternatives and process for volunteer dismissal.   You'll leave this 2-hour in-person workshop with: Tools to create effective volunteer boundaries and set expectations An understanding of the varied reasons that volunteers break rules Tips and techniques for managing and improving volunteer performance The basics of volunteer dismissal processes Light refreshments will be provided.  How to find the venue: Crohn's and Colitis Canada's National Office is located at 439 University Avenue, Suite 2110 (21st floor), at the intersection of Dundas Street West and University Avenue in downtown Toronto. You can reach this location via subway at St. Patrick Subway Station, or via the Dundas (505) streetcar. The Boardroom is located within the Crohn's and Colitis Canada office on the 21st floor, our team will greet you outside the elevator to help you find your way.     Community Guidelines  Volunteer Toronto is committed to fostering a space where everyone is welcome to show-up and engage without fear of harassment. During the registration process, you will agree to our Community Guidelines: you understand that harassment or perceived harassment of individuals and/or organizations participating in this space will not be tolerated. The host reserves the right to remove participants from the space (with registration fees refunded) if such harassment or perceived harassment occurs.  Registration & Cancellation Policy  Registrations are accepted at the discretion of Volunteer Toronto. No refunds will be issued for cancellations received within 48 hours of an event. Registration can be transferred to another member of your organization. Written notice must be received more than 48 hours prior to the event date in order to receive a refund. Please send your written cancellation to Sammy Feilchenfeld at sfeilchenfeld@volunteertoronto.ca. Registered participants who fail to attend an event will be invoiced for the full fee, due 30 days from the date of the invoice.
location: Crohn's and Colitis Canada National Office 439 University Avenue Suite 2110 Toronto, Ontario  M5G 1Y8 Canada

description: Are your volunteer program policies and procedures following the rules? Are you up to date on the necessary legislation that applies to your volunteers? In this interactive online webinar, we'll explore the policies, procedures and legislative connections you need to have in your volunteer program, from compliance with the Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA) to appropriate disclosure on police checks. We'll also discuss the changing nature of volunteerism in updating policies, procedures and codes of conduct. Please note: This session will not be recorded.     You'll leave this 90-minute webinar with: A detailed distinction of which laws and regulations apply to volunteer programs Tools to align volunteer program policies and procedures with Ontario legislation A set of policy and procedure examples that are necessary for successful programs even without legislative links Community Guidelines  Volunteer Toronto is committed to fostering a space where everyone is welcome to show-up and engage without fear of harassment. During the registration process, you will agree to our Community Guidelines: you understand that harassment or perceived harassment of individuals and/or organizations participating in this space will not be tolerated. The host reserves the right to remove participants from the space (with registration fees refunded) if such harassment or perceived harassment occurs.  Registration & Cancellation Policy  Registrations are accepted at the discretion of Volunteer Toronto. No refunds will be issued for cancellations received within 48 hours of an event. Registration can be transferred to another member of your organization. Written notice must be received more than 48 hours prior to the event date in order to receive a refund. Please send your written cancellation to Sammy Feilchenfeld at sfeilchenfeld@volunteertoronto.ca. Registered participants who fail to attend an event will be invoiced for the full fee, due 30 days from the date of the invoice.

As a leader of volunteers, you may be responsible for event planning, implementation and volunteer support. In this interactive, 90-minute webinar, we’ll explore the event volunteer engagemnent process to prepare you for event success. Learn about why events are an important part of non-profit programs and services, considerations for in-person and online events, and key volunteer roles in planning, coordination and day-of implementation. Plus, we’ll take a deeper look into setting up evaluation and debrief processes that can help you make future events even better.     You'll leave this 90-minute webinar with: An understanding of the volunteer cycle with event planning Tips and techniques for before, during and after-event volunteer engagement Tools for assessing event success and volunteer engagement between events Community Guidelines  Volunteer Toronto is committed to fostering a space where everyone is welcome to show-up and engage without fear of harassment. During the registration process, you will agree to our Community Guidelines: you understand that harassment or perceived harassment of individuals and/or organizations participating in this space will not be tolerated. In this workshop, we will explore power dynamics in the workplace and discuss how we can collectively work to distribute power more equitably to foster greater inclusion. Participants will unpack concepts such as "power over," "power within," and "power with" while investigating the intersections of identity, power, and privilege. Together, we will reflect on the power we may unknowingly hold and the influence we have, gaining deeper awareness and practical strategies to create more balanced and inclusive environments.   About the Speaker   Sheliza Jamal is a graduate of Harvard University and is the founder and Executive Director of Curated Leadership Inc., a coaching firm that fosters partnerships with leadership teams, nonprofits, and corporations to develop their knowledge in the areas of equity and diversity to build inclusive communities. Sheliza is a certified Ontario Educator and is currently completing her PhD at OISE, University of Toronto in the Department of Social Justice Education with a research focus on anti-racism in Teacher Education Programs.  Sheliza brings over a decade of experience in designing curriculum and implementing training and development programs aimed at addressing inequitable outcomes for underserved and equity-seeking communities. She engages participants in dialogue about oppression and uses a calling-in approach to bring people together to listen, learn, and lead with empathy.  Sheliza currently serves as a board member of the Harvard Graduate School of Education Alumni Council and is a Founding Member of the Harvard Alumni Entrepreneurs Council Canada. She is also a board member for WorkInCulture.     Community Guidelines  Volunteer Toronto is committed to fostering a space where everyone is welcome to show-up and engage without fear of harassment. During the registration process, you will agree to our Community Guidelines: you understand that harassment or perceived harassment of individuals and/or organizations participating in this space will not be tolerated. The host reserves the right to remove participants from the space (with registration fees refunded) if such harassment or perceived harassment occurs.  Registration & Cancellation Policy  Registrations are accepted at the discretion of Volunteer Toronto. No refunds will be issued for cancellations received within 48 hours of an event. Registration can be transferred to another member of your organization. Written notice must be received more than 48 hours prior to the event date in order to receive a refund. Please send your written cancellation to Sammy Feilchenfeld at sfeilchenfeld@volunteertoronto.ca. Registered participants who fail to attend an event will be invoiced for the full fee, due 30 days from the date of the invoice.

event_name: Happy Black Futures Month From Onika Powell, Artistic Director
description: The privilege many of us hold comes with the power to create real change. It’s not enough to simply acknowledge the issues and achievements—it’s also our responsibility to actively engage, educate ourselves, unlearn harmful systems, and create space for safety, equity, and creative expression. Using our influence to amplify Black voices and support Black artists is what we should take away from this month.   For those of you who are new to VIBE (and as a reminder to our long-time supporters), one of the ways we support the Black youth artists in our community is through our NExT program. In its sixth year, we continue to use mentorship and networking to empower Black youth artists across the GTA. The collaborative approach to our mentorship program has created pathways for exposure while working towards breaking down barriers and increasing visibility. As always, Black artists and allies alike, the success of this program relies on working together to create lasting change through funding/donations, access to networking opportunities and resources, as well as community support… so that means mark your calendars for March 20th as we launch Black Futures Exhibition 6.0. The event will showcase the powerful work of 10 Black Creatives, who truly deserve this spotlight and recognition. These artists are shaping the future, and we are inviting you to be part of their journey. With our partner TO Live, we will take over the Meridian Arts Centre to showcase this brilliance. We can’t wait to see you there!

Lab Outcomes  By the end of this lab, you will have:  Broad knowledge of the technical requirements and competencies of the non-profit executive director role. Best practices in leadership and people-engagement, mission impact, governance and operations. Started a personalized 12-month action-plan to identify and execute on key objectives to support your success as a first-time executive director.

event_name: Volunteering on (Non-Profit) Boards: Why and How to Join a Board
description: Learning Outcomes: By the end of this workshop, you will be able to:  Identify different types of non-profit organizations, non-profit leadership and decision making. Assess your strengths, opportunities, and availability for various forms of volunteer work in non-profit organizations. Examine expectations and risks associated with being a Board member. Identify practical next steps to look for and select from available board opportunities. Suggested Participants: This workshop is ideal for people who are new to the non-profit sector in British Columbia, want to develop a better understanding of its leadership and decision-making processes, and are looking for ways to engage in their communities and express their voices.  Workshop Benefits: Learn how to express your voice in your community. Expand your knowledge of community engagement. Expand your network. Learn about other people’s volunteer experiences. Thank you to our partners VCH Health Promotion Community Investments for their generous support of this learning opportunity!

event_name: BC Societies Act Fundamentals with PLEO
description: Are you thinking of starting a non-profit? Are you new to a board? Need a refresher on the Societies Act?   As a result of Vantage Point’s long lasting partnership with Pacific Legal Education and Outreach Society, in this workshop we will review key issues: membership structure, board composition, General Meetings procedure and content, Conflicts of Interest, Record-Keeping and Dissolution. By the end of the workshop you will know the key information you need to comply with the Societies Act.

Learning Outcomes: By the end of this workshop, participants will be able to:  Educate the board on their governance role. Develop tactics to assist the board in setting direction vs. managing operations. Demonstrate seven daily tasks to effectively lead leaders. Suggested Participants: Executive directors or equivalent role (CEO, Managing Director)​.  Workshop Benefits: Through our Executive Director: Empowering Your Board workshop, you will develop:​  Better relationships with your board members. An educated board that focuses on their role and respects yours as executive director.

event_name: Volunteering on (Non-Profit) Boards: Why and How to Join a Board
description: Learning Outcomes: By the end of this workshop, you will be able to:  Identify different types of non-profit organizations, non-profit leadership and decision making. Assess your strengths, opportunities, and availability for various forms of volunteer work in non-profit organizations. Examine expectations and risks associated with being a Board member. Identify practical next steps to look for and select from available board opportunities. Suggested Participants: This workshop is ideal for people who are new to the non-profit sector in British Columbia, want to develop a better understanding of its leadership and decision-making processes, and are looking for ways to engage in their communities and express their voices.  Workshop Benefits: Learn how to express your voice in your community. Expand your knowledge of community engagement. Expand your network. Learn about other people’s volunteer experiences. Thank you to VCH Health Promotion Community Investments for their generous support of this learning opportunity!

Learning Outcomes: Come away from this workshop with the ability to:  Define the responsibilities of board members. Describe the three modes of governance. Describe practices that build effective boards. Learn new tools that support good governance (e.g. consent agendas, board calendars). Suggested Participants: All non-profit boards and leaders.  Workshop Benefits: Confidence to carry out your role as a board member. Clarity on the roles of board members vs. the roles of staff and operational volunteers. An inclusive space to review and reflect on what it means to be a board member.
location: In-Person at the Vantage Point Office

event_name: Raising the Right Revenue: A Fund Development Lab
description: Lab Outcomes  By the end of this lab, you will be able to:  Speak simply and persuasively about your cause.​ Identify realistic strategies to raise and diversify resources.​ Identify key elements of membership development.​ Solicit a major gift or grant with confidence.​ Describe the fundamentals of creating a business plan.​ Describe the characteristics of both contributed and earned revenue streams.​ Use mission-based prospecting to align donors and funders to your own mission and strategic plans.​ Describe restricted and unrestricted funding and the basics of financial management.

Tune in 6 AM to 6 PM on Tuesday, February 25, 2025 for the University Hospital Foundation’s Heart Pledge Day on up! 99.3.  Heart Pledge Day is the day we fill the radio waves with the true, inspiring and personal stories of physicians, patients, medical researchers and healthcare providers to raise awareness about the life-saving cardiac care at the Mazankowski Alberta Heart Institute (Maz).

Are you an Internationally Educated Health Professional looking to advance your career in Ontario?  The Active Career Connect & Engagement Project for Internationally Educated Health Professionals (ACCEP-IEHP) will be hosting an online information session to share how the program supports Internationally Educated Health Professionals (IEHPs) integrate into the Canadian labour market.  Program Highlights:  Subsidized Work Experience Individualized Accreditation and Career Planning Career & Employment Readiness Training Canadian Workplace Culture & Equity, Diversity & Inclusion (EDI) Workshops Mental Health and Wellness Sessions One-on-One Support and Guidance Mentorship Opportunities Eligibility:  To be eligible for this program, you must:  Be a permanent resident, naturalized Canadian citizen, or a person granted refugee status in Canada Be an Internationally Educated Health Professional (IEHP) Have no Canadian work experience or be employed less than 20 hours per week Have a Canadian Language Benchmark (CLB) of 6 or higher Join us to learn how this program can help you take the next step in your career in Canada!  For more information, contact us at accep-toronto@success.bc.ca.

event_name: The Roses That Grow from Concrete - Youth Gangs and Gun Violence Symposium
description: On behalf of Victim Services of Durham Region, Child & Youth Advocacy Centre, Region of Durham, and UOIT, we are pleased to invite you to the 2025 Youth Gangs and Gun Violence Symposium.  Tupac Shakur, a well know rapper who also died by gun violence once wrote a poem entitled The Rosses that Grew from Concrete. In this poem he argues that like a rose growing from concrete marginalized youth, even with their gifts are continuously viewed as "broken", "sick" and problematice. Such narratives about racialized/marginalized and Indigenous youth have led to not only stigmatization (criminal gang members), but control the so-called problem or threat. However, critical scholars including those with lived experience in the streets/gangs have argued that the narrative that has been created about gang/gang violence is not only inaccurate, but also inclomplete. As such the policies that have been designed to mitigate the issue, including criminal justice responses, have failed these youth.  This symposium seeks to address the following questions:  What is a gang? Why do youth join gangs? What are the mental health implications of gang membership and violence? How do youth survive/navigate the streets? How do youth exit gangs or a street life? What can practioners do?
location: Regent Theatre Ontario Tech  50 King Street East Oshawa, ON L1H 1B3 Canada

event_name: BYS x Sheridan Presents Empowering Futures -  Black Girls in Trade Summit
description: Get ready for an exciting and empowering experience at the Empowering Futures: Girls in Trades Summit!   This interactive event introduces Black girls in Grades 8-12 to skilled trades. Parents can join but are not required; youth may attend independently.  Packed with hands-on activities, inspiring stories from successful Black women in trades, and opportunities to explore careers you may never have considered, this summit is designed to spark curiosity, break down stereotypes, and open up a whole new world of possibilities.
location: Sheridan College (Davis Campus - Magna Building) 7899 McLaughlin Rd Brampton, ON

description: Join us for the Skills for Change Spotlight Series, a virtual panel discussion facilitated by CEO Surranna Sandy, where we bring together experts and advocates to discuss pressing issues impacting equity-seeking communities.    This session, in alignment with Black History Month, will focus on Gender Equity and Intersectional Challenges—exploring the barriers faced by Black women, trans, and nonbinary individuals in achieving representation and economic security. Despite progress, these communities continue to experience workplace discrimination, wage gaps, economic inequality, and heightened vulnerability to gender-based violence.    Key Discussion Points:    ✔️ Workplace Discrimination: The impact of bias, underrepresentation in leadership, and barriers to career advancement.  ✔️ Economic Inequality: Pay gaps, employment challenges, and the overrepresentation of Black women in precarious jobs.  ✔️ Gender-Based Violence: The disproportionate risks faced by Black women, trans, and nonbinary individuals and the need for systemic support.  ✔️ Pathways to Change: How organizations, policymakers, and communities can drive real solutions for inclusion and equity.    As an organization committed to empowering underrepresented groups, Skills for Change aims to foster meaningful conversations that lead to tangible action.    🎟️ Register now to be part of this critical conversation!

event_name: A National Caregiving Strategy for Canada
description: Caregiving touches the lives of millions of Canadians, yet it remains overlooked in public policy. Caregivers—both family members and professionals—face mounting challenges that demand urgent solutions.  The Canadian Centre for Caregiving Excellence (CCCE) is leading the way with its groundbreaking National Caregiving Strategy, co-created with caregivers, care providers, researchers, and health leaders from across the country. This strategy presents practical, transformative solutions to Canada’s caregiving crisis.  Join us for an inspiring and thought-provoking session where you’ll: • Gain insights into the components of the National Caregiving Strategy. • Hear from caregivers who shaped its development. • Learn how you can join our movement to make Canada the greatest place in the world to give and receive care.  Whether you’re a caregiver, policymaker, or advocate, this is your chance to help transform caregiving in Canada. Let’s work together to build a future where care is valued, supported, and celebrated.

event_name: Call for Interest: 2025 Workshop – Mothers’ Return to Work After Childbirth: Mental Health and Family Well-Being
description: Research shows that mothers’ earnings stagnate and often decrease following childbirth, leading to a large and growing gender pay gap. This is often referred to as the “motherhood penalty”. In response to this, considerable work has focused on policies which may facilitate the return of mothers to the workplace. However, knowledge remains scarce regarding the implications of the timing of this return on maternal mental health and on children’s development.    In a research project funded by the Vanier Institute of the Family, we seek to address this gap. In this context, we are organizing an workshop looking at various family structures, Indigenous parents, racialized parents, etc. If you are interested, please see the call for interest for more information.  At this stage, we are looking for individuals and organizations interested in participating in the workshop. These may include academic and non-academic researchers, policy makers, practitioners, etc. Individuals who wish to attend but not necessarily present may also contact us to receive updates.   Workshop Objectives:   Knowledge mobilization. Mothers’ return to work and maternal mental health are often considered separately in research and policy spaces. Our first objective is to address this; namely, to:  a) Bring together experts from various domains, including fields that have done more to bridge the gap between these two issues; and    b) Help further the conversation around the intersection of these topics.   Stakeholder engagement. With the expansion of affordable child care, the current policy context is a great opportunity for researchers to engage with policy makers and practitioners around:  a) What works best for families; and    b) How the expansion’s success could or should be evaluated going forward.   Conversation around data challenges and opportunities. Despite advances, important data gaps continue to restrict our ability to answer policy-relevant questions in this space. Our third objective is to engage with others to:  a) Identify the various data limitations individuals and organizations are facing; and   b) Discuss how existing data may be leveraged to circumvent some of these limitations.   Tentative Date and Location: The workshop will be held in Ottawa in the spring of 2025: May 15, 2025.   To express interest in participating in or attending the workshop, or for additional information, please email Dr. Simard-Duplain at gaelle.simardduplain@carleton.ca.    Organizers:   Dr. Tímea Laura Molnár, Assistant Professor, Central European University   Dr. Gaëlle Simard-Duplain, Assistant Professor, Carleton University   With financial and organizational support from The Vanier Institute of the Family

Lunar Lore combines the work of Hanna Yokozawa Farquharson (Saltcoats), Savannah Holt (Saskatoon), and Zoë Schneider (Regina) in an exhibition that bathes the viewer in the full embrace of the moon. Fibre, ceramics, and sculpture illuminate the varied ways these artists approach the moon as inspiration. Working with themes of cyclicality, time, consistency, and ritual, Lunar Lore offers a journey through the many ways we know the moon, speaking to its universality of themes.  Cyclicality, circles, and spheres are central to the flow of the exhibition, encouraging the viewer to succumb to the natural pull of the lunar influence. Lunar Lore invites appreciation for fine craft, stimulating ideas, and a warm embrace, making for a unique yet inviting viewer experience.
location: Savannah Holt, Zoë Schneider, Hanna Yokozawa Farquharson

description: Run4Lighthouse is our largest annual fundraiser to help ensure our services remain free for families who need them, so no child has to grieve alone. For event sponsorship opportunities, please contact Angela at amallard@lighthousegriefsupport.org
location: Spencer Smith Park 1400 Lakeshore Rd., Burlington, ON L7S 1B3 Burlington

description: Focus on MPN: PV, ET and MF

event_name: Evolution of therapies for myelofibrosis (MF): From palliation to disease modification
description: Myelofibrosis (MF), a form of myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN), is a rare cancer where the bone marrow makes too many of one kind of blood cell. In MF, the abnormal cells cause normal bone marrow to be replaced by scar tissue. Over time, the fibrous scar tissue makes it harder for the bone marrow to produce normal blood cells. Fortunately, research into NMPs has meant that we are seeing an evolution in treatments and management.  In this 1-hour live webcast, Dr. Vikas Gupta, Hematologist at the Princess Margaret Cancer Centre in Toronto, will review MF and the evolution in diagnosis, treatment options and aspects of follow-up care.

event_name: Understanding essential thrombocythemia (ET): Diagnosis, treatments and follow-up care
description: Essential thrombocythemia (ET) is a type of myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN). People with ET have too many platelets, a type of blood cell. Too many platelets can result in a blood clot (thrombosis) forming in a blood vessel.  In this 1-hour webcast, Dr. Lynda Foltz, University of British Columbia, will review this type of MPN, diagnosis, treatment options and aspects of follow-up care.

event_name: Understanding polycythemia vera (PV): Diagnosis, treatments and follow-up care
description: Polycythemia vera (PV) is a type of myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN). This group of blood cancers features too many blood cells of a particular type made in the bone marrow. MPNs begin with one or more changes to the DNA of a single stem cell in the bone marrow. These changes cause the stem cell to create more and more abnormal stem cells.   In this 1-hour live webcast, Dr. Sonia Cerquozzi, hematologist at the Tom Baker Cancer Center and Peter Lougheed Centre in Calgary, will review this type of MPN, diagnosis, treatment options and aspects of follow-up care.

This year’s comedians, Freddy Proia, Allie Pearse, and Juliana Rodrigues will be performing both nights, and will surely have you howling all night!

description: Submissions are now open for Ingenious+!    Ingenious+ gives young changemakers a chance to start realizing their ideas through financial support, learning opportunities and mentorship from leading Canadian innovators!  Categories include:      🤝 Community Engagement  🌍 Climate & Environment  📣 Equity & Inclusion  💚 Health & Well-being  🚀 Technology & Entrepreneurship    Ingenious+ is empowering young Canadians aged 14-18 with the chance to win up to $10,000, along with networking opportunities and mentorship, to bring their ideas to life.  The deadline to apply is February 28.

The London International Youth Science Forum (LIYSF) offers a two-week science summer camp in the UK, held both online and in-person, at Imperial College London & The Royal Geographical Society. Each year, 500 students aged 16-21 years old from 70 countries enjoy the 15-day STEM summer camp, with lectures and demonstrations from leading scientists, scientific visits to world-class laboratories and scientific universities, combined with international cultural interaction.  The in-person LIYSF fee, which includes accommodation, meals and the two-week program is £3,295 GBP (approximately CAD$5,900) plus return airfare, which you arrange yourself. Students can also participate in LIYSF virtually. The virtual LIYSF fee, which includes on-demand access to view content throughout the event including main lecture demonstrations and select scientific visit content, as well as online networking and live chat features, is £325.00 GBP per student.  The LIYSF organizing committee is offering Canadian students a £150 discount per student in-person attendees, and a £50 discount for virtual attendees.
